pros:

Good benefits package

Inefficient/complacent staff
Ineffective middle management

As in many large companies, leaders set great values & visions for the company but don't necessarily have a reliable way to ensure management upholds these values. Mid-year & annual performance reviews are done to align the company, but many managers see this as a formality. They don't use the opportunity to set ambitious goals to create value or grow. I've been told by management that personal ratings are not based on whether you achieve or exceed your goals, but rather are predetermined, by pecking order, to justify promotions (that are often based on tenure, not capability). This of course depends on the group you're in. Some are excellent, some are stifling.

It plays out in office politics every day. There are also fewer women in senior leader positions - it is subtle, but men have greater opportunities to develop and advance. I am quite sure if someone lifted the cover we would find gender-based pay inequity.

review_title: I've been an employee of Suncor for over 10 years and I can say that this company is one of the best I know.
pros: I've been exposed to numerous technical challenges that kept me interested and focused. One is given plenty of developmental opportunities specially throughout the starting years (as a new grad or junior engineer), but you must be ready to take them. They will take you far, that's for sure. Even though they may involve moving in other provinces.
cons:
Opportunities knock at your door, but you must open your door and embrace them. Otherwise, you're  finding yourself stuck in the same position for many years. 
Rotation program for new grads is very good for the individuals, but not for the department they leave behind.
With the exception of 2012/2013, previous years lacked any kind of technical training or development. There is not much interest in preparing and grow inside talent, but rather is more interest to pay outside consultants.

review_title: The Only Thing Worse Than Failing is Succeeding
pros: Suncor has some great people and job opportunities within its vertically integrated multi-divisional structure.  The company is positively involved in the communities it has operations in, has some great soft compensation elements, including matching charitable donations, fitness allowance, and generous vacation policy.  The company is committed to Safety in the work place and has baked that commitment into the corporate culture.
cons: Suncor talks the talk of meritocracy, but walks the walk of mediocrity.  This is evidenced in the poorly executed annual goal setting and review process, little to no interest from middle and senior management in process improvements, and weak follow through on company wide initiatives.  There is very little work-life balance parity between teams within a function.

pros: Salaries lightly higher than industry average, but this difference is disappearing fast.
cons: Lets face it, living in Fort Mac is the pitts! The only reason I came here is for the money. Now that incentive is being eroded. Allowances cut back and staff being laid off and demoted. The town has also taken a big step backwards after the wildfires. Once you are appointed, Suncor expects you to go the extra mile, but when it comes to saving money, they just care about the numbers and not about the individuals. Zero training allowed over the last few years. Zero career advancement, unless you are one of the 'chosen few'. Ruthless staff cuts while upper management grows. Beware, it is a dog-eat-dog world out here. I would have left long ago if the job market elsewhere was better...

review_title: Top heavy, poor choice of management, semi-exclusive atmosphere.
pros: I was happy about the opportunity for growth, the company's values and their commitment to safety and raising the bar in all areas.
cons: Most of the time the vision/values/mission/etc., was nothing more than signage and verbiage, with very little buy in from front line workers, and none from management. Very top heavy: there was a director for a better part of a year with not a person reporting to him. The company touted themselves as somewhere that work-life balance was important, but there was nothing done to support this, only changes made to make balance more difficult. An experience with a director who seems to belittle  my career aspirations in a conversation about long term goals.

job_title: Process Engineering COOP in Fort McMurray, AB
pros:
Great experience working as a process engineering co-op at Suncor's bitumen upgrading facility in Fort McMurray. 

Technical work with field experience that utilizes courses taught in university for chemical enigneering students.

In my opinion no better experience can be gained in oil and gas industry, considering oil sands is always pushing the limits of production, as opposed to well established refineries and other downstream facilities.
cons:
Can be demanding job at times. 

Co-op students are given a great deal of responsibility, as well as required to have a term project (every 4 months), which they present to management, director and GM of process engineering.

pros:
Low to mid level staff collaborate well and will work together to get things done.

Decent salary and benefits
cons:
Very political in upper management and lack of collaboration.

Evaluation of employees is more of a popularity contest than based on performance as the system is bell curved and only so many can get high bonuses.  Also difficult to manage career as most position moves are decided via upper management who do not consult leaders on skills, capabilities and preferences.

Lack of business knowledge in IT so the business wants to improve, standardize and automated, but IT is a road block so several manual work around have been developed.

review_title: Become friends with the right people and it's great. Great employee won't get rewarded.
pros: Good salary and compensation incentives.
cons:
Work environment is poor, I have witnessed preferential treatment due to friendships, and employees wishing to learn more and better themselves not given opportunity. 

The self assessment that bonuses are based off of are not fact checked and I have had other employees admit to me that they fluff their assessments up so they can get a good bonus.

People look after themselves. Speaking up about changing something for the better will get you negative attention. Better to be silent and keep your head down, or be a "yes man". 

Instead of proper training on systems such as SAP, other user interfaces tend to be made to try and make things simpler. Knowledge passed on from person to person leading to broken systems and inconsistencies.

pros:
Competitive pay and benefits
Some very talented and well intentioned employees 
Large size and diverse businesses provide some good personal growth opportunities
cons: Senior Leadership has no respect for employees and do not live up to their espoused values in terms of people. Very quick to let employees go when things get tough, tend to fire more employees than necessary then rehire younger, less experienced and less expensive replacements. Frequent practitioners of ageism and have a well earned reputation for providing departing employees with less than competitive severance packages.

review_title: Great pay and learning opportunity, but too much "we've always done it this way" attitude
job_title: Reliability Engineer in Fort McMurray, AB
pros: Great compensation, I was making $65K a year as a CO-OP STUDENT. Double pay for overtime, lots of vacation, company provides temporary housing, great learning opportunity about the industry, awesome people
cons:
- crappy location, site gets VERY dusty in the summer, potential health hazard
- engineers have virtually no power over the blue collar workers (mechanics, operators etc.) impossible to get something done by the unionized guys, strong sense of "us vs. them" attitude, 
- felt little value in my work, like tiny cog in giant wheel
- large number of incompetent people

review_title: Great Place To work, if you're in the right team
pros: Very challenging and exciting work if you have the right management and team. Because of Suncor's matrix structure, it is all about where you fall in the organization and your team. This also makes it very heard to move around as well - especially to the Petro-Canada division. Internally, it still feels like two separate organizations. Would love for there to be more integration! But other than that, because it is Canada's largest energy company, you get to experience rewarding and amazing work.
cons: After the lay-offs and re-organization, the company has become unbearable! Maybe its because there is a lack of engagement, or lots of incompetent managers were left that don't care about new members of the team, but I know I'm giving my notice ASAP... even in this economy and without a job lined up. Is this the start to a sinking ship?

review_title: Suncor's Finance Leadership Are Incompetent Liar's
pros: Pay and Benefits are the only Pro's at Suncor.
cons: I was managing a group of 10 people and was asked to go on project to be a project manager.  After 36 months of doing absolutely nothing in my project management role and given a demotion (because there was no projects to manage) I was given a severance package.  18 of the 36 months I didn't even go into an office.  I literally set at my house, watched TV and played on social media.  I worked for Suncor for 28 years and this is how they treat people.  I would have never agreed to go on project if I had known that there was no project to manage.  Basically Suncor's management wanted to find a job for another manager so they lied to me, back filled my position and then gave me nothing to do for 36 months before they laid me off.  Can you say Constructive Dismissal (it's a legal term)!

review_title: I experience many different activities and interactions through the course of my workday - it's not boring!
pros: I believe I receive satisfactory remuneration for the work I do and am happy with the year end 'bonus' which all employees share in.  I'm provided with a multitude of experiences (and challenges) in my work and it's very interesting.
cons: Some days it's a little overwhelming and you need to prioritize your work.  I think some areas of the company run too lean in terms of manpower (front line) and others have too much fat (office and I hazard to say a lot of Directors, GM's, VP's)

review_title: Still (even in this economy) a high compensation company
pros: I would say hardly 15% or less people would be getting total emoluments less than $100k per year. Mostly transparent atmosphere; Good resources within the corporate teams. Benefits, amenities and support services are excellent.
cons: Due to few disgruntled senior employees, real contributing employees are overlooked- quite common in large org. Org structure is still heavy on top (VP + Directors) even after restructuring. there are instances where single digit # of employees are reporting to  such individuals. There is potential to reduce the cost/ waste in materials, contracts (particularly projects), employee benefits (like cell phones, benefits) and in travels.

pros: Pay scale is competitive, benefits package is excellent (healh/dental/vision, FSA/DCFSA), flex day program for FTEs, strong end-of-year compensation, 401k and pension
cons: Cronyism is rampant - if you have a good relationship with someone higher up, then you are set even if you don't necessarily have the skill set or interest for a job at the next level.   It really is about who you know.  Also, be prepared to toe the party line - if you want to think outside the box or promote some strategies that management didn't think of first, Suncor may not be the place for you.

review_title: The Commerce City Refinery is a great place to work, good pay and benefits.
pros:
- Great starting pay, would be hard to find anything in that area that could complete with. 
- Health and dental benefits were outstanding as well as a pension & 401k. 
- Coworkers were all great and the USW employees all worked as a family
cons:
- The refinery is fairly old and starting to show its age and some units and equipment could use a overhaul.
- Plant managers come and go so often it seems like they use this site as a springboard to move up, so not much incentives to spend money on improvements.

pros:
Corporate Culture! - majority of the people interactions were awesome. As a student I felt like I was well accepted and they encouraged my learning and my goals. You are able to talk to Directors and other Managers easily as they are super friendly.

Training- was able to attend multiple training session for excel,systems and even information session about O&G and what Suncor was about. 

Community Involvement greatly encouraged.
cons:
Worked during layoff season and it was really interesting to see but that put extra load on the team and less opportunities to learn more in-depth concepts outside my tasks. 

Enforced buddy/mentoring program- although there is a proposed buddy system at Suncor not all groups abide by this. A more formal mentoring program with a higher up employee would have been awesome to get to know more about Suncor and help with my career development.

review_title: Company has major problems with a culture of bullying and harassment
pros: Salary, benefits, and flexible time.
cons: The organization is highly hierarchical with an old boys club mentality. Very cut throat. There is a lot of bullying and harassment from management in the company that contradicts the lip service of diversity and inclusion. Forgot reporting any harassment to HR as they will not do anything to resolve issues. They are there to support management and not the employees. They will not even return your calls if you report bullying or harassment. Bullying and harassment seems to be a culture that is accepted as the people who are the offenders do not get terminated. The company is backwards in todays standards of being a healthy respectful workplace. I have seen many people leave the company because of this culture. Until they clean up management and remove the offenders, this company may not be a good place to start a career.

review_title: Great people, but not enough challenge
pros:
Great people and team dynamics - people were friendly, willing to help and work together.
Awesome pay, benefits, bonuses and incentives.
Tons of vacation and flextime.
cons: There was not enough challenge in the role and personally I felt that my role was an over-hire and not needed.  I spent a lot of time twiddling my thumbs despite asking for more work.  It is and was a great company, with great people I am still in touch with, but unfortunately I couldn't sit around waiting for work.

pros: Good company. Good benefits including 401K match and pension. People are generally nice and its a fun place to work. The recent change in upper management as improved employee morale and made the workplace better.
cons: Pay is low compared to other companies, but bonuses make up for the lower pay. There are not many opportunities in the US. Have to move to Canada to move up in the company.

review_title: Working for a integrated energy company
pros: The integration of upstream and downstream into one organization presents a lot of opportunity for anyone who wants to get to know the energy business. The have a wide range of business units that are located around the globe. During boom times it is possible to move laterally into new careers and gain access to career development opportunities that wouldn't be possible with a smaller energy company.
cons: Your success in the corporate culture will depend a lot on your ability to build positive relationships quickly. This includes have a leader who is skilled at building relationships as well. The company is also heavily dependent on commodity prices that are influenced at the international level. This means that your position could be quickly eliminated if commodity prices drop and the company needs to quickly reduce its costs.

pros: There is a lot of opportunity for career growth. Salaries are competitive with other large oil and gas companies. The office environment is very nice. Excellent on-site perks - daycare, gym, etc.
cons: The company is very hierarchical and does not value efficiency. They spend more time writing up processes than fixing things that are not working. Project take longer and cost more than they should because too many approvals need to be obtained.

review_title: It used to be a great company......
pros: The financial compensation that included salaries, bonuses etc was excellent.   The benefits were good.
cons: Terrible leaders. Passive aggressive colleagues. Poor opportunities for advancement if you are not an engineer. Every year management would initiate silly programs  so that they could pretend they were accomplishing something.  Leaders would spend a lot the shareholder's money to come up with a new name, and waste everyone's time with these projects,  but these initiatives never went anywhere.   The merger ruined Suncor's culture - too bad.

pros:
Some very good people working here, but are limited by the politics and by the way things have been done for the past 10 years.
I believe the culture will change with the new management team, but it will take another 5 years at the minimum to change direction and attitudes of how things are done at Suncor
cons: Promoting people who are not qualified for positions and no recourse to correcting the situation. Suncor does have a MOR ( Manager once removed....talk to your managers immediate supervisor) , but the feedback you provide does go back to your immediate supervisor, that makes the situation even worse.. The MOR is a joke!

job_title: Travel Services Representative in Calgary, AB
pros: Great environment, friendly people, company seemed to appreciate their employees as they showed it by giving, for eg. balloons and chocolate out to each rep, because it was a busy time and everyone was chipping in great.  Nice supervisors. Reps felt supported.
cons: Its not very easy to get a foot in!  Even though I was under contract, I wasn't called on in the future to have another opportunity, even though they are out there.  I enjoyed my time there, just wish I could get back in, especially since I wouldn't need any training as I have already done the job and learned their systems.

pros: Unlimited potential for hard work.
cons: Due to the unlimited potential, if you climb too high, the ax is sure to find you... It's a marathon, not a 100m dash. Set a pace you can sustain and stick to it.

review_title: A big company with a lot of opportunity
job_title: Human Resources Advisor in Calgary, AB
pros: Suncor's the largest company in Canada, very stable and compensation is great. There is interesting work if you're willing to get your hands dirty and try something new. Suncor has great work/life balance and there is opportunity to grow but you have to find it for yourself.
cons:
The company is still going through a lot of growing pains...
- processes are difficult, unestablished and hard to follow
- the company is on a journey to "operational excellence" but it's not well understood by the employees and management isn't walking the walk
- there's a lot of grey area when it comes to accountability and performance management
- there's a lot of duplicate work and working in siloes

job_title: Technical Staff in Fort McMurray, AB
pros:
Flex Days help with work life balance
Ability to gain a wide variety of experience by moving between groups.
Good Benefits for now
cons:
Compinsation incentives seem to be based on favourtism with managers and is inconsistant between groups. There is poor communication between groups and groups tend to work in silos. Extra effort tends to go unnoticed. Advancement is limited to Type A, agressive personalities.  
High turnover of staff of late leading to excessive workloads and unrealistic expectations from managers.
Benefits slowly being stripped away.
Professionals are overtime expempt but a technologist doing the same job is overtime eligible.

pros:
Suncor has good processes in place and a good work culture.    
High quality work and projects
cons:
Like any large company, sometimes process impedes work getting completed in a swift manner.  
Due to current state of the industry, its difficult to get hired full time permanent and the pay for most roles, despite the requirement of significant experience, is low.
Suncor appears to place a high degree of emphasis on diversity, but age is certainly not a factor that is being considered. Despite my extensive experience, there is strong drive to hire junior people at Suncor.

pros: Interacting company to work for; especially with projects which help to increase the skills, knowledge and responsibility for managing Sustainable Development Projects
cons: Lack of understanding from the business managements within the reign of NAME. It's unfortunate as the oil price went down the company start to reels their staff also wit the security issues within some countries the company did take the initiative to move their people around within the company in order to keep them as they have very long years of experience, poor management decisions ultimately took over.

pros: Excellent FIFO package and flight provider (WestJet) including the best camp facilities that I have come across. Staff are more than willing to help you, encourage you, motivate you to improve skills to be able to move into higher positions.
cons: How vacation is allowed to be taken requires some added unnecessary logistics with traveling on weekends. 3 days or 4 day allotments during one shift set is a little inconvenient.

review_title: Good company, Fort Hills is too new to comment on.
pros: Great opportunities, lots of great people. structure in the workplace is well thought out and the training program is in depth - albeit not completely finalized.
cons: Fort Hills needs improvement in HR policies on vacation, travel from hubs & the "annual incentive" isn't a performance bonus as much as they would like you to think it is based on your personal achievements and effort.

pros: Suncor offers excellent compensation and benefits.  As an integrated oil & gas company there are numerous opportunities for skilled professionals.
cons: Suncor ELT and corporate functions have a tendency to roll-out too many new initiatives at the same time.  This creates conflicting priorities and puts added strain on operational resources who are trying to meet production requirements.  Continual restructuring and reorganizing makes it extremely difficult to meet operational goals - the target is always moving.

pros: Comp and benefits plans are top notch.
cons:
Very poor leadership in the controllers group.  Most senior finacmce leaders have little to no operational experience. Those that do below them  that do have that experience appear to be seen as threats.  
Strategic focus is lacking.  Once again senier finance leadership doesn't seem to know what direction they want to go...however this lack of focus somehow translates into lower level mgrs and staff not knowing what they are doing.  
Many senior leaders, manage up and do not focus. Or care about developing lower level talent. 
From a finance perspective I would seriously think twice about joining suncor.   There are smaller and better run organizations which would provide a much better experience.

review_title: Productivity and cost savings over happiness
pros: Good pay and the experience looks good on a resume, housing is provided for students in fort mcmurray which is a huge cost saving and the housing is very nice.
cons: In the fort mcmurray office, everyone is miserable, no one wants to communicate with you or help you with your job let alone furthering your career. Suncor places no value on employee happiness and this is very apparent. From the dirty, out of date offices to the lack of team building/corporate events, nothing about this company is about creating happier employees. Numerous full time employees are leaving and it's not hard to see why. Pay can only make up for so much when the work environment is tragic.

review_title: Changes are needed with Turnaround Group and Maintenance Department
pros: "Safety first" is stressed at all levels. Good pay and benefits. If you are in the right department with good leadership, you can expand your knowledge and experience tremendously.
cons: Too many managers at US refinery(mainly Canadian), still voice the safety first motto, but push production before all else. Little concern over working people long hours or under adverse conditions. Safety incidents are not reported or falsified to ensure manager bonuses. Starting to fade from the work/life balance, and expectiing folks to work longer hours. Promotion and hiring of unqualified or incompotent leaders, becuase they don't question authority and have low moral value.

pros:
Thorough mentorship and guidance as an intern
Many opportunities for networking with peers and superiors
Quality and quantity of work given to me was good and appropriate for my background (not just arranging folders and filing because I am an intern/co-op)
cons: In my experience, there were no real downsides in working with Suncor. It is a large company, so it can take a lot of effort in both your work and networking to really stand out and rise to the top. This is a con for people who are not good at or who don't like the networking aspect.

review_title: Was good till 2008-post merger is a sweat shop
job_title: You Know Who I Am in Calgary, AB
pros:
Name recognition as Canada's largest oil company. 
Will hire immigrants
 You can make mistakes and not get caught-poor culture of accountability
cons:
Very political environment--merit has nothing to do with  promotions
Petty tyrants in corporate functions like Supply Chain, Finance, HR--piss off the wrong person and you are toast
Lack of respect for people--sweatshop with excessive hours in Finance, HR, Supply Chain functions
Good people are leaving in droves for other opportunities with competitors
Pay is poor compared to rivals--HR SVP has confused aging CEO that Suncor is in top quartile.
New hires are getting paid way more than good existing employees--worsening the attrition
They keep talking about Operations Excellence--in reality company is anything but that
Lack of direction, training and goals

pros: Salary and Bonus were good.  Lots of training opportunities were given.  When Times were good (high oil price) atmosphere was great with social events, volunteering, etc.  Benefits are good.
cons: Typical 'large corporation' problems.   Hard to get promoted, a lot of middle managers are in positions they are not qualified for because they've been there a while or have high up contacts.  A lot of decisions get made that seem ridiculous.  Sometimes hard workers are forgotten in the mix while good talkers get promoted.  When oil crashed, it was dog eat dog, layoffs, cancellations, re-orgs, etc..

pros: Best place to work (specially for a new grad). Suncor has clear mission, vision and strategy to guide everyone in the company. Excellent pay and benefits!
cons: Don't expect your qualification alone will be enough to excel in this company, you need to know your everyone around you, particularly your internal clients, very well.

pros:
Safety culture is far above peers in oil sands industry
Personable people create a family like atmosphere
Advancement opportunities available
Non - union 
Management creates a welcoming and stress -free atmosphere allowing for great working relationships
Beautiful amenities for remote workers
cons:
Advertised Saskatoon as a hub and then cancelled it on their employees
Among peers in oil sands it has the an average benefit package
Among peers in oil sands it has the lowest pay scale
Average pension plan 
"Lockdown" culture during work hours -  contacting son, daughter, wife, husband during lunch breaks or coffee breaks is strictly forbidden and prohibited

job_title: Human Resources Projects in Calgary, AB
pros: Great place to work, many different opportunities for career path, easy to move within organization, great pay compared to competitors and fair evaluations. Company has seen success even in some of the toughest years, and has a very loyal employee base. Lots of subject matter experts, high tenure employees and flexibility for work life balance.
cons: Very bureaucratic, middle and senior management heavy, heavy on processes and opportunities to streamline especially with decision making. Missing the mark on engagement especially for younger generation, could spend a little more time on succession planning for front line leader levels.

pros: During the high oil times, company was rewarding and offered good benefits.  Working environment was good and safety always at the forefront of operations.  Starting off in EIT programs offered good opportunities to get as much experience as possible.
cons: Once oil prices dropped, employees just became a number.  Bean counters in corporate took over and decimated the workforce to bare minimum.  Culture really shows during bad times.  It's unfortunate as this was a great company to work for but when push comes to shove, poor management decisions ultimately took over.

pros: The pay is decent, bonus is great and PTO's are a bonus to have.  Suncor has great values to help everybody work towards the same goal.
cons: There are leaders and managers that don't deserve to be here.  Some leaders and managers feel that they can do whatever they want.  Its the people that make working at Suncor hell.  Its too bad there is no survey to let Directors/VP's know how their direct reports are performing.

job_title: Engineer Co-op Student in Fort McMurray, AB
pros:
-Great people
-Extremely knowledgeable front line
-Heavy exposure to heavy mining equipment
-Free accommodations in a 2bed 2bath apartment
-Coach buses to and from work
-Relocation benefits
-Discounts through SERA
cons:
-slow to implement changes
-mindset of certain engineers/senior engineers in the company is not the best
-not the most ideal place for a mechanical engineer to work as most actual engineering is done by contractors.
-what little engineering needs to be done is more or less trivial and straightforward.
-steep learning curve at first with no background, but levels off pretty quickly and becomes stagnant.

pros:
One of the biggest companies in Canada which will look good on CV
Straight talking management
Fairly low levels of work pressure stemming from undemanding expectations
cons: Management is accustomed to directing rather than leading, hence senior managers lacking intellectual acumen in being able to handle simplest questions outside of their comfort zone

review_title: Great place to work where strong performers are handsomely rewarded.
pros: Suncor provides limitless opportunities to learn and tremendous leverage to define one's role and grow in one's career. This does not mean only promotion in ranks/titles necessarily, but the personal journey to become the best or indispensable in one's chosen field.
cons: Performance review and succession planning processes, although well defined, are not employed consistently and may not have good transparency. This can be unfair to many good performers who are not proficient in organizational politics.

review_title: Good exposure, but lacks structure within the company
pros: Largest oil sand crude oil producer in Canada after merge with Petro Canada. Lots of opportunities to experience hands-on activities supporting operations. Friendly and easy going environment.
cons:
Lacks structure in HR, disorganized, only and most probable route to promotion is by the amount of time you stay in the company. Need lots of motivation to be able to achieve your career development. 
People lack sense of urgency when projects involve co-workers from other departments.

job_title: Maintenance Planner in Fort McMurray, AB
pros: Learning experiences. And words because I need more.
cons: Fort Mac is expensive.  Managers lie about everything.  Many people told unlimited OT here, there isn't.  Planners are limited to 40hrs/month.  This only applies to the pets of the leads, all others get less or nothing.  No communication from higher ups on moves made.  Pay is not top of the industry, only way to make money is the limited OT.  Ever changing rules for planner expectations and duties.  Currently removing 20K per year LOA and changing housing program in a bad way.

pros: Good place to work, great pay and benefits and very safe environment.
cons:
If you are not a 'good fit' you can always have your bags packed (like I had when they came for me). Fit is determined by who you know and where you went to school. Woe unto you if you crossed the Atlantic and the Sahara Desert on your way. Management is very unprofessional and autocratic.
A nice place if you don't know anything, don't plan on knowing something and plan on never doing a days worth of work.
All in all great experience.

pros: In the position that I fill, they are very generous with flexible time working from the office or from your home.  Additionally, I feel that their insurances and compensation packages are competitive to the industry.
cons: It is a HUGE company which means that things don't always move quickly or in ways that always make sense.  Being a publicly traded company on more than one stock exchange means that the bottom line can often be the driving factor in financial choices, which leads to operational setbacks

review_title: Excellent place to work with great people and leadership.
pros: Good work environment with great pay, benefits and vacation time. Leadership has a clear direction for the future and the company is relatively stable due to the integrated business model.
cons: Many high performers make for a competitive environment but it drives creativity. Dated systems make for manual workloads but company is currently in process of revamping data systems. Political climate in Canada makes it difficult for the company to grow.

pros: Suncor has been a great place to work, as the employees here have been more than welcoming and always willing to answer any questions I have while I learn my new position. Safety is always number one and I have been very impressed with the quality of life here at Suncor. It is truly a great place to be a part of.
cons: I have no negative comments to say about my experience here.

review_title: Large company with lots of issues
pros: good pay, lots of vacation/time off, if you get in with the right people you can sail on to retirement with little work
cons: Management only cares about impressing those above so they can climb the corporate ladder; you get ahead by who you know not what you do; leaders are clueless as to what subordinates actually do; leaders don't treat all team members equally; development goals are useless as you are forced to put down what your leader wants you to develop and not what you actually want to develop; leaders/mgrs will stop you from moving within the company if they don't want you to leave the dept even if it's on your development goals; some depts will hold employees to staying 2 yrs while other depts will allow you to move in less time which clearly shows which managers genuinely care about supporting their people and not hindering development; very heavy workload and no recognition for extra effort; lots of lip service with little action/things take way too long to change/progress/be completed;  technology is 5 years behind other oil and gas companies; hardly any training to do your job; job description is not what the job actually is; HR provides no support if you need it; money is allocated to wrong areas and therefore wasted; managers often make decisions based on their opinions and don't consult the people who may may truly know better; lack of synergy across the company; overall way too many politics.

pros: Great pay, great people, all very friendly and encouraging. Lots of extra courses are offered for free if you would like to expand your knowledge.
cons: When you apply for a summer position they will randomly select a position for you. So if you are an accounting major, you might get a finance job.

review_title: It is one of the best places in the industry one can work for.
pros: Salary, benefit, bonus and other incentives. Excellent training program, great opportunity for growth. Integrated oil & gas company, upstream portfolio diversified in many areas including in situ, oil sands and conventional resources.
cons: No hedging gets the company vulnerable to the decreasing oil price. Going through cost cutting, employee reduction, going through reorganization, in this process loosing valuable human resources after spending years of training and development on them.

pros: Salary, wide variety of exposure, great people
cons: Easy to get lost among the masses. Not a great company to work for if you wish to climb the corporate ladder. Very much a political company - you need to cozy up to the right people if you want the advancement opportunities. It is discouraging to have your abilities judged on popularity.

pros:
Suncor is a company for a specific type of employee. Following are some general advantages that anyone will find positive:

- Lots of technical in-house training
- Many kind people who have spent their lifetime (or will spend their lifetime) working at Suncor.

If you are the type of person who:
- dislikes ambiguity
-enjoys working with pre-defined processes
-likes an extremely slow pace of work, or to be more particular, is OK with fast-paced useless work which results in slow-paced achievement of results
-wants to opportunity to try out a lot of different roles (lateral moves)
-is OK not having contact with the real decision makers and isn't overly interested in how the business operates as a whole, in effect, you enjoy working in your "box" 

If you are the type of person who fits the criteria I outlined above, you may very well love working for Suncor. The pay is about average, vacation is about average and you will never be very busy or stressed about anything important.
cons:
If you are the type of person who meets the following description, then Suncor is not the right place for you to work:

- thrives on challenge
-is stifled by process 
- is results oriented
- is innovate, particularly in process related ways
-is entrepreneurial
- is a fast learner and gets bored very quickly

If you meet the above criteria and work at Suncor, it will suck every last drop of happiness out of you and the hardest thing you do will be putting a smile on your face and pretending you like your job. Suncor is a bureaucratic behemoth of an organization with a solid 8 levels of management and low-level managers who sit through meetings, feeling like they're making a difference, while collecting detailed information on the tasks their subordinates completed on a weekly basis.
